title: Saudi Arabia Set to Return to Normal Oil Production Levels by End of Month
text:
Saudi Arabia will soon restore most of its oil output and return to normal production levels in weeks, the country’s energy ministry said Tuesday, following the attacks last weekend on the country’s facilities that hobbled the world’s largest oil exporter.

Seeking to calm global markets reeling from the weekend attacks, newly appointed Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman said the kingdom is using reserves to supply oil to its customers at pre-attack levels and that normal production of 9.8 million barrels a day will return by the end of September. Some Saudi officials said a return to normal will take longer.

The kingdom has restored 50% of production lost in Saturday’s attacks, but won’t restore its total capacity for a few months, Prince Abdulaziz said.

Saudi Arabia hasn’t directly accused Tehran of mounting the attacks, but the country is increasingly confident that Iran directly launched a complex missile and drone attack from its southwestern territory on Saturday that battered the kingdom’s oil industry, said people familiar with the investigation.

Related Video Saturday’s attack on a Saudi oil facility could have long-lasting repercussions. Heard on the Street editor Spencer Jakab explains how it could impact the global markets. Photo: Hamad I Mohammed/Reuters

Offering few details about the damage to specific facilities, Prince Abdulaziz painted a picture of a resilient national industry rising from the ashes. But he also said the kingdom’s cushion of production capacity—which normally includes idle wells capable of pumping out two million barrels of crude a day—won’t be fully restored until the end of November.

Some Saudi officials say restoration efforts will take even longer than the oil minister outlined Tuesday. “The damage is severe,” a Saudi official familiar with the matter said.

On Tuesday, Prince Abdulaziz alluded to Iran’s involvement in the attacks and a series of assaults in recent months on oil vessels in the Persian Gulf and infrastructure in the region. “This modus operandi has been escalated,” he said.

The price of Brent crude—the global benchmark—jumped 15% to $69.02 a barrel on Monday, its largest one-day climb since 1988. It then fell back 6.5% to $64.55 a barrel on Tuesday.

For decades, oil markets have relied on the Saudi Arabia’s output flexibility to turn on and off its spigots in times of global crisis. For at least the next 10 weeks or so, Saudi Arabia would likely be unable to step in to fill global supply gaps in the event of another disruption, foreign or domestic.

Saudi Arabia expects its Abqaiq facility to return to pre-attack normal production levels of about 4.9 million barrels a day by the end of September, but it will take the kingdom until November to restore its full production capacity of 12 million barrels a day.

The destruction at Abqaiq oil-processing facility and Khurais oil field cut off roughly 5.7 million barrels a day in production, about half the country’s total output and some 5% of global oil supply. The attacks came as the state-owned Saudi Arabian Oil Co., also known as Aramco, prepares for a two-stage initial public offering. Aramco hopes to raise as much as $100 billion in the dual debut, which would make it the biggest IPO ever.

Prince Abdulaziz, the son of King Salman, said the offering won’t be affected by the attacks. The company had planned to debut on the Saudi stock market before the end of the year, The Wall Street Journal reported, and then float its shares on a yet-to-be-chosen international exchange sometime in 2020 or 2021.

In the same press conference on Tuesday, Aramco Chairman Yasir al-Rumayyan said the oil firm was committed to an IPO in the next 12 months.

Saturday’s assault was the largest-ever attack on Saudi oil infrastructure and now poses the biggest geopolitical and economic test for 34-year-old Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdom’s day-to-day ruler. The royal has sought to wean his oil-dependent country off oil by introducing social and economic reforms, and the threat of conflict could upend those plans.

As Saudi officials review information coming in from the U.S., Kuwait and their own investigators, they are focusing on southern Iran, near Iraq, as the likely launchpad, the people said.

The drones and missiles appeared to have flown low to the ground, so that they weren’t detected by Saudi radar or defense systems early on Saturday morning, according to the people familiar with the investigation.

Investigators have found debris that appears to be Iranian cruise missile technology, the people said.

“Everything points to them,” said a Saudi official who wasn’t authorized to speak to the media, referring to Iran. “The debris, the intel and the points of impact.”

Iran has denied any involvement in the attacks in Saudi Arabia and in the Persian Gulf.

Abqaiq is the world’s biggest facility of its kind, with a maximum production capacity of 7 million barrels a day. It draws crude from the kingdom’s massive oil fields and separates it from gas into specific grades, which are sold to customers largely in Asia, such as China, Japan and Korea.

With Abqaiq normally processing highly prized light crude, Aramco has asked buyers in India and China to load grades of lesser quality until at least early October, traders say. That has increased demand for light crudes to similar grades in the United Arab Emirates and Iraq, they said.

The loss in natural-gas liquids associated with crude has also diminished supplies of ethane, propane and butane sent to Saudi petrochemical company Sabic, said Saudi and European oil officials.

Prince Abdulaziz was more bullish on Tuesday than Saudi officials have been in recent days. At least two of seven of Abqaiq’s stabilization facilities were severely damaged and have to be rebuilt, which could take months, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.

In recent days, company officials have reached out to oil buyers, officials at the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, analysts and consultants with an upbeat message: Any immediate shortfall can be covered by oil in storage, and normal supplies should be restored within three weeks.

Some in the kingdom say they even see a silver lining in the incident. “The crisis can help the IPO,” said a Saudi oil adviser. “It’s a good opportunity for Aramco to show it can manage its supply chain well.”

The adviser said the kingdom’s pressing need to raise cash through the listing was a powerful incentive to avoid an escalation with Iran.

“Saudi Arabia doesn’t want war with Iran because it wants to save the IPO. They can’t have both,” said the Saudi oil adviser.

Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman also needs the IPO to make up for $30 billion in losses from the Saudi sovereign fund, the adviser said.

One European oil executive who spoke to personal contacts at Aramco said he was told the repairs would take months. The executive said the repair efforts will require ordering made-to-measure equipment, which would need to be shipped from abroad and then tested.

description: Saudi Arabia will soon restore most of its oil output and return to normal production levels in weeks, the country’s energy ministry said Tuesday.
